newsitem.title: JAPAN: NTT seen helped by cell phone boom, Internet.
newsitem.headline: NTT seen helped by cell phone boom, Internet.

text.p: Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp (NTT) is battling to survive as policy-makers fight over whether to break up the telecommunications giant, but all is at least calm on the earnings front.
A cellular phone boom and soaring demand for communication via computers are boosting domestic traffic, benefiting NTT, which has a monopoly over Japan's local networks.
"The basic (earnings) trend is up as increasing city-call traffic is helping NTT's earnings structure," said Hironobu Sawake, an analyst at Nikko Research Center.

But NTT, threatened by calls from the powerful Posts and Telecommunications Ministry to break it up, will continue to face heavy pressure to slash long-distance call rates and the fees for using its city-call networks, both criticised as too high compared with international standards, Sawake added.
The government, which owns 65 percent of NTT, has postponed a decision on whether to split it up until next year. NTT itself opposes being split into three different firms.
In the current business year to the end of next March, NTT will receive a big chunk of money from cell phone operators for using its local networks.
Analysts expect access charges paid to NTT by cell phone operators to easily top 200 billion yen ($1.80 billion) during the year, up from 125.8 billion yen ($1.13 billion) in 1995/96.
This is on top of an expected 235 billion yen ($2.11 billion) in access charges from long-distance call operators such as DDI Corp and Japan Telecom Co.
"Deregulation...and an activated telecommunications market mean more customers for NTT," said Toshiho Sato, an analyst at UBS Securities Ltd.
Various new communications services are planned next year, such as cut-rate long-distance call services by leased line operators, which all use NTT's network.

Eric Gan, an analyst at Goldman Sachs, expects NTT's profits from local calls to catch up with those from long-distance calls within two years, buoyed by new services and a rise in the number of users accessing the Internet through personal computers.
Long-distance call services now account for 75 percent of NTT's parent operating profit.

Despite the booming traffic, however, analysts expect NTT's parent current profit to stay mostly in line with its own estimate of around 234 billion yen ($2.10 billion) this business year, due to planned cuts in long-distance call rates and access charges.
Current profit is pre-tax, and includes profits and losses from non-operational activities such as stock investments.
NTT has pledged to open up its network to rival telephone operators at "appropriate costs" and cut long-distance call rates by early next year.

Analysts predict NTT's current profit for the half-year to be around 110 billion yen ($990 million), against 126.78 billion yen ($1.14 billion) a year earlier, as large rate cuts implemented in March will affect earnings.
NTT's cuts in access charges, on the other hand, will benefit its long-distance rival Japan Telecom.

Makio Inui, an analyst at Salomon Brothers (Asia), has revised upward his forecast for Japan Telecom's parent current profit in 1996/97 to 48 billion yen ($432 million) from an earlier forecast of 39 billion yen ($351 million).
NTT will disclose parent half-year results and full-year forecasts on November 22 and Japan Telecom on November 21. ($1=111 yen)
